description: This is a reading-intensive course, intending to be a survey of current topics in neurolinguistics. It is divided into three parts. Part I is about foundational concepts and methods, and I’ll give lectures. Part II is about language representation and processing, which covers the important topics of this field. I`ll briefly introduce these topics and provide background knowledge at the beginning of the class, and the rest of the class will be student presentations on assigned readings (20-25 minutes each) and class discussion. The presenters will have to email me their question(s) for discussion by Monday midnight and give me their PowerPoint slides no later than Wednesday midnight so that I can upload them onto Moodle. Part III is group project presentations. Each group (2 people per group) will research a topic pertaining to neurolinguistics (topic submission by 5/4), which can be something not covered in class, and do a 45-minute PowerPoint presentation followed by a 15-minute Q & A session. The group has to assign an article for the class to read that can help them understand the presentation (assigned reading submission by 5/25—electronic file only). This article can be selected from a scientific journal, a popular magazine, or an academic/non-academic book. Each individual is required to turn in a term paper on the presented topic (i.e. short review article) by the end of the semester (6/22 term paper due). Everyone is welcome to review more literature in the term paper that is not presented in class. Maximum page limit for the paper is 10 pages (12 point font, double-spaced, one inch margins).
goals: foundational concepts and methods of current topics in neurolinguistics
syllabus:
Week 1 Overview of this course & course survey

PART I: FOUNDATIONAL CONCEPTS AND METHODS

Week 2 Introduction to neurolinguistics (and brain basics)

1) Pinker S. & Jackendoff, R. (2005). The faculty of language: what’s special about it? Cognition, 95:201–236.

2) Ingram, J. C.L. (2007). The neuroanatomy of language. In Neurolinguistics: An introduction to spoken language processing and its disorders (pp. 40-65). Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. \[electronic resource\]

3) Brown, C. M., & Hagoort, P. (1999). The cognitive neuroscience of language: Challenges and future directions. In C. M. Brown & P. Hagoort (Eds.), The neurocognition of language (pp. 3-14). Oxford: Oxford University Press.

Week 3  Aphasia and language

1) Benton, A. & Anderson, S. W. (1998). Aphasia: historical perspectives. In Sarno, M. T. (Ed.). Acquired Aphasia (pp. 1-24). San Diego: Academic Press.

2) Damasio, A. R. (1998). Signs of aphasia. In Sarno, M. T. (Ed.). Acquired Aphasia (pp. 25-41). San Diego: Academic Press.

Week 4 Neuroimaging techniques and language: ERP & fMRI

1) Osterhout, L., McLaughlin, J. & Bersick, M. (1997). Event-related brain potentials and human language. Trends in Cognitive Science, 1 (6), 203-209.

2) Kutas, M. & Schmitt, B. M. (2003). Language in microvolts. In M. T. Banich & M. Mack, Mind, Brain, and Language (pp 171-210). Mahwah NJ: Erlbaum. \[esp. after p. 180\]

3) Rugg M. D. (1999). Functional neuroimaging in cognitive neuroscience. In C. M. Brown & P. Hagoort (Eds.), Neurocognition of Language (pp 15-36). Oxford University Press.

PART II: LANGUAGE REPRESENTATION AND PROCESSING

Week 5  Speech perception I

1) Naatanen, R. (1995). The mismatch negativity: A powerful tool for cognitive

neuroscience. Ear and Hearing, 16, 6-18.

2) Naatanen, R., Lehtokoski, A., Lennes, M., Cheour, M., Huotilainen, M., Livonen, A., Vainlo, M., Alku, P., Ilmoneimi, R. J., Luuk, A., Aillk, J., Sinkkonnen, J. & Alho, K. (1997). Language-specific phoneme representations revealed by electric and magnetic brain responses. Nature, 385, 432-434.

3) Shtyrov, Y., Kuhala, T, Palva, S., Ilmoniemi, R. J. & Naatanen, R. (2000). Discrimination of speech and of complex nonspeech sounds of different temporal structure in the left and right cerebral hemispheres. NeuroImage, 12, 657-661.

Week 6 Speech perception II

1) Van Petten, C., Coulson, S., Rubin, S., Plante, E., & Parks, M. (1999). Timecourse of word identification and semantic integration in spoken language. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition, 25, 394-417. \[2 presenters\]

2) Ischebeck, A. K., Friederici, A. D. & Alter, K. (2008). Processing prosodic boundaries in natural and hummed speech: An fMRI study. Cerebral Cortex 18, 541–552.

Week 7 Meaning I

1) Kutas, M. & Hillyard, S. A. (1980). Reading senseless sentences: Brain potentials reflect semantic incongruity. Science, 207, 203-205.

2) Kutas, M. & Hillyard, S. A. (1984). Brain potentials during reading reflect word expectancy and semantic association. Nature, 307, 161-163.

3) Kutas, M. & Federmeier, K. D. (2000). Electrophysiology reveals semantic memory use in language comprehension. Trends in Cognitive Science, 4, 463-470.

4) Van Petten, C. (1995). Words and sentences: Event-related brain potential measures. Psychophysiology, 32, 511-525. \[2 presenters\]

Week 8 Meaning II

1) Shapiro, K. & Caramazza, A. (2003). The representation of grammatical categories in the brain, Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 7, 201–206.

2) Barber, H. A., Kousta, S.-T., Otten, L. J., & Vigliocco, G. (2010). Event-related potentials to event-related words: Grammatical class and semantic attributes in the representation of knowledge. Brain Research, 1332, 65-74.

3) Swaab, T., Brown, C. & Hagoort, P. (2003). Understanding words in sentence contexts: The time course of ambiguity resolution. Brain and Language, 86, 326-343.

Week 9  Syntax I

1) Osterhout, L. & Holcomb, P. J. (1992). Event-related brain potentials elicited by syntactic anomaly. Journal of Memory and Language, 31(6), 785-806.

2) Osterhout, L., Holcomb, P. J. & Swinney, D. A. (1994). Brain potentials elicited by garden-path sentences: Evidence of the application of verb information during parsing. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition, 20, 786-803.

3) Kaan, E. & Swaab, T. (2002). The brain circuitry of syntactic comprehension. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 6(8), 350–356.

Week 10  Syntax II

1) Friederici, A. (2002). Towards a neural basis of auditory sentence processing. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 6(2), 78–84.

2) Grodzinsky, Y. & Friederici, A. D. (2006). NeuroImaging of syntax and syntactic processing, Current Opinion in Neurobiology, 16, 240–246.

3) Ullman, M. T. (2004). Contributions of memory circuits to language: the declarative/procedural model. Cognition, 92, 231–270. \[2 presenters\]

Week 11  Language production (Submission of final project topic due)

1) Van Turennout, M., Hagoort, P. & Brown, C. M. (1998). Brain activity during

speaking: From syntax to phonology in 40 milliseconds. Science, 280, 572-574.

2) Indefrey, P., Brown, C. M., Hellwig, F., Amunts, K., Herzog, H., Seitz, R. J. & Hagoort, P. (2001). A neural correlate of syntactic encoding during speech production. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 98, 5933–5936.

3) Heim, S., Opitz, B., Müller, K. & Friederici, A. D. (2003). Phonological processing during language production: fMRI evidence for a shared production–comprehension network. Cognitive Brain Research, 16, 285–96.

Week 12  Language development

1) Dehaene-Lambertz, G., Hertz-Pannier, L. & Dubois, J. (2006). Nature and nurture in language

acquisition: Anatomical and functional brain-imaging studies in infants. Trends in Neuroscience,

29(7), 367–373.

2) Kuhl, P. K. & Rivera-Gaxiola, M. (2008). Neural substrates of early language acquisition.

Annual Review of Neuroscience, 31,511–534.

3) Bates, E., & Roe, K. (2001). Language development in children with unilateral brain injury.

In C.A. Nelson & M. Luciana (Eds.), Handbook of developmental cognitive neuroscience (pp.

281-307). Cambridge, MA: MIT Press.

Week 13  The bilingual brain

1) Fabbro, F. (2001). The bilingual brain: cerebral representation of languages. Brain and Language. 79, 211–222.

2) Abutalebi, J. (2008). Neural aspects of second language representation and language control. Acta Psychologia, 128, 466–478.

3) Clahsen, H. & Felser, C. (2006). How native-like is non-native language processing? Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 10(12), 564-570.

4) Kotz, S. A. (2009). A critical review of ERP and fMRI evidence on L2 syntactic processing. Brain and Language, 109, 68-74.

Week 14 Sign language (Submission of group project assigned reading due)

1) Neville, H. J., Coffey, S. A., Lawson, D. S., Fischer, A., Emmorey, K. & Bellugi, E. (1997). Neural systems mediating American Sign Language: Effects of sensory experience and age of acquisition. Brain and Language, 57, 285-308.

2) MacSweeney, M., Capek, C. M., Campbell, R. & Woll, B. (2008). The signing brain: The neurobiology of sign language. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 12(11), 432–440.

3) Campbell, R., MacSweeney, M., Waters, D. (2008). Sign language and the brain: A review. Journal of Deaf Studies and Deaf Education, 13, 3–20. \[only needs to present pp. 8 -20\]

PART III: FINAL PRESENTATION ON VARIOUS TOPICS

(Details will be given in May)

Week 15  Final project presentation (I)

Week 16  Final project presentation (II)

Week 17 Final project presentation (III)

Week 18 Summary & Term paper due
